children.subject: I dropped 61b and 61c once and retook them so I have an ok gpa, but because I was struggling through these programming or algorithm courses, I pushed 189 to junior spring so I don’t have any ML research experience, which also makes me worried about applying to master program...

Thanks for raising the point. 

Can anyone with experience comment on this?  Is that really true that a GPA of 3.4 is a killer for a good master program?
unless you have extensive research experience and a good GRE, probably.
same anon as above, didn't think through it clearly. if you have difficult course workloads most semesters, admissions may understand.

What a nice question! Similar situation here, maybe a bit worse. I consider myself as a very mediocre programmer since all my coding experiences are just from 61AB and I did them okay(B+, A- with Hilfinger) but never enjoyed the process. However, I love ML and classes like 134, 110, data 100, cs189(dropped later due to lack of prereq) and enjoyed solving tough questions from homework and discussing them with friends. But ironically, I also did not do well among those classes..... So, as a rising senior now, my GPA(around 3.4) definitely cannot support me for entering a Ph.D. program, even not a good master program, I guess. So, I'm struggling should I insist on learning ML related course like 126, 127, 189 182 and pursuing a Master degree or just be more realistic to prepare for the software engineering interview.

history.content:
I'll provide another perspective.

I've a lot of SWE experience with side projects/hackathons and I've take CS C100/188/189/182 and the fundamental math/stats classes (mostly lower div). I'm currently doing an ML Engineer internship, officially SWE though, productionizing ML models at a big company I interned at last summer at which time I did full-stack web dev. My advice would be: although a lot of MLE positions want at least a masters, you can still try to get a MLE position because companies doing applied ML might be more lenient and if that doesn't work out, get a SWE job and after some time try to do an internal transfer (which shouldn't be too hard) to a team that does SWE+ML or just ML. My current work is like the second scenario since I was originally assigned purely backend SWE work this summer but I asked to switch projects due to my interests in ML and my manager and mentor were supportive of that probably since they knew I was capable of good work from last summer.

Other anecdotal advice I have is: if you don't want to go the SWE->MLE route, try aiming for MLE roles at startups which usually have more lenient hiring standards than established companies. I did an ML Engineer internship at a startup this spring and the interview was easy and the ML work was very applied due to the nature of the solution they wanted; I also worked on productionizing the models.

If anyone has questions, feel free to ask in the comments!

------

Just wanted to share my experience and weigh in on this as I have similar interests and am currently interning on an applied ML team at a large software company.

TL;DR yes it's totally possible to get into ML work, but you'll need some luck and at least some software engineering chops.

My team has 7 full-time engineers, of which 1 has a PhD in an unrelated field (computer architecture), 2 have spent time in related PhD programs, and the rest are all bachelor's degree holders, including my mentor (UC Berkeley EECS, graduated in the last 2-3 years). I'd say the common thread among most of them is that they took a lot of related courses and were able to dabble in ML through some time in a research lab or with personal projects. My mentor was able to take a lot of what are now considered the "canonical ML track" courses (189, 126, 127) along with some more project- or reseach-focused classes (294-112, 294-131, what eventually became 182, etc).

However, my mentor was very candid with me about how landing this position took a good amount of luck- he was doing plain old backend dev for a year until his current manager joined the company, provided a proof of concept for a deep learning project requiring extra headcount, and brought him along when he spun off a new partner team. Of the rest of the engineers, half were hired externally with more relevant experience, while the other half transferred from other teams internally and had little ML chops to begin with, but our manager was already familiar with them and confident in their engineering ability.

As far as the day to day work goes, the team does a lot of interesting stuff but it's not the same as research- there's a lot of feature engineering, architecture tweaks, experiments with different loss functions, and other small scale exploratory work which occasionally will lead someone to read papers or meet with folks in the company's research division. But I'd say that at least 2/3rd of the time the team spends goes towards strictly engineering efforts- building data pipelines and monitoring tools, and even properly designing and writing the modules that are used to construct the models our team uses (think like 1000s of lines of Python & Tensorflow). Because at the end of the day, the team is still building a software product, it just happens to be a product that does deep learning, and it requires first and foremost a good foundation in software engineering. My manager spent most of his career working on and leading these sort of projects and in his experience, the most successful ones have teams that prioritize good engineering and design. So maybe you won't be able to avoid it completely, but it's still totally possible to work on the data structures/algos/good systems & architecture stuff and get better at it while you do (I certainly feel like that's happening to me right now).

children.subject:
Responder with the Berkeley grad as my mentor here!

1) I asked him the same question and he said that generally being familiar with how to implement and train deep neural networks and having the intuition for debugging them when they don't work is helpful- he gained that by taking a few of the deep learning 294. This is for a team that primarily does deep learning, not sure how it goes for other stuff.

2) this is going to vary between companies and even within a company's teams, so it's hard to say. Might want to ask around and get a sense of how the companies you're applying to handle that (obviously if a company doesn't use ML in it's products then there will be no such opportunities)

Good luck!

This is the other MLE responder:

  • My first recommendation would be CS 182. After that (or concurrently) try to do ML/DL 294s as mentioned above, but they aren't strictly necessary. Also, a lower priority recommendation would be Data 100 if you have the time (you can self learn the material more easily than the other classes).
  • I wouldn't agree with absolute wording like *all* companies, but definitely many big companies have formal (periodic events) or informal (just randomly asking other teams) processes for doing so. I can't speak for small or mid sized companies since their operations vary a lot.

Thank you! Do you have any recommendation for senior year to help me prepare for becoming mle in the future? (I think internal transfer is a very good path since I’m also ok with general swe). Courses I’ve taken that are related to ML may be CS 188, CS 189, STAT 134 and STAT 135. What courses should I take further? Also, are internal transfer generally workable in all companies? Thx so much!

history.content:
I am a rising senior and currently debating on whether to pursue a master's degree. I feel like I am more skilled at the math side of CS since I did well in 70, 189, 134 but did not very well in 61A, 61B, 61C, 188 (I found 188 a lot harder than 189). Courses I enjoyed most are Rao's 70 and Shewchuk's 189. However, I found that software companies mostly hire full-stack or infrastructure engineers but very limited machine learning engineers. If I don't plan to get a PhD, is it possible to get into ml with a master's degree? What does machine learning engineer generally work on? Thx for advice!

Sometimes I think it's ok to just work as a software engineer since during internship I realized that jobs don't really require any knowledge from school, but it just seems a little bit strange to me to work on software engineering since I am not good at data structures, algorithms, systems... However, ML path seems only suitable for very very top students who have a lot of A+ and hold PhD degrees, so I am kind of lost about what I should do next.
history.subject: How hard it is to find a job as a machine learning engineer?

history.content:
I am a rising senior and currently debating on whether to pursue a master's degree. I feel like I am more skilled at the math side of CS since I did well in 70, 189, 134 (scored 0.6sd to 1.5sd higher than mean on all exams in these courses, top 10% in CS 70 final) but did not very well in 61A, 61B, 61C (hardest course ever... took it last fall with Garcia and never scored higher than average), 188 (I found 188 a lot harder than 189, always scored higher than mean a little bit), 170 (took once and dropped it after first midterm, scored lower than mean 1sd). Courses I enjoyed most are Rao's 70 and Shewchuk's 189. However, I found that software companies mostly hire full-stack or infrastructure engineers but very limited machine learning engineers. If I don't plan to get a PhD, is it possible to get into ml with a master's degree? What does machine learning engineer generally work on? Thx for advice!

Sometimes I think it's ok to just work as a software engineer since during internship I realized that jobs don't really require any knowledge from school, but it just seems a little bit strange to me to work on software engineering since I am not good at data structures, algorithms, systems... However, ML path seems only suitable for very very top students who have a lot of A+ and hold PhD degrees, so I am kind of lost about what I should do next.
